awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Low Cost, Large Scale Production of Biocidal Micropowder by a Reversed Arc, Plasma-Fluidized Bed Reactor
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is based on the improvement of respiratory equipment and personal protective equipment (PPE). Commercially available face masks, gowns, filter media and other PPE are contaminated through environmental exposure, posing a threat to healthcare personnel.  The proposed solution is a high-surface-area antiviral/antimicrobial micropowder which can be applied to PPE surfaces. Improved protection from infections and reduced cross-contamination may result in fewer deaths, decreased healthcare costs, and increased economic productivity. The addressable global PPE market was $23 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow through 2028, while the global disposable face mask market was valued at $792 million in 2019, and the inclusion of other types of PPE increases this estimate further. The COVID-19 pandemic is driving the demand for these products, though the applicability of the proposed technology is not limited to COVID-19. The proposed product will be material that can modify the surfaces of fabrics with active antiviral properties, leading to improvements in health and safety. The customer base is expected to be healthcare personnel, pharmaceutical and food manufacturing facilities, the public, and manufacturers of PPE, medical devices, textiles, and filters.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to improve the antiviral/antimicrobial properties of respiratory equipment and PPE, which is typically only passively protective, is difficult to decontaminate and re-use, and can lead to worker exposure during changing and handling. The proposed solution is a high-surface-area micropowder, coated with an antiviral/antimicrobial coating, which can be applied to PPE surfaces. Unlike current technologies, the particle size, morphology, surface area, and topography can all be tailored for specific biocidal activity. Additionally, powder shape and surface quality can be customized to enhance adhesion. The proposed project is to develop a prototype powder product formulation that allows easy application of antiviral (copper alloy) coated particles to fabrics and other materials. This technology is based on a fluidized-bed, plasma-enhanced deposition process for synthesizing unique core-shell micropowders of metal, ceramic, or highly-shaped nanoforms of carbon, including proven biocidal materials. The synthesized microparticles will have high surface-to-weight ratios making them better suited for capturing micro-organisms while also having improved bonding to surfaces of filter media and PPE materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF STTR Phase I Outcome report

Healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) cost between $28 and $45 billion and result in more than 100,000 deaths annually in the United States. Investing in infection prevention can lead to improved patient outcomes and reduced costs for healthcare organizations. Because of this, the prevention of HAIs is a major financial consideration of the entire healthcare industry.

This project is to develop a series of products based on copper-coated micropowders with unique antiviral/antimicrobial/antifungal properties. Such powders can be applied to high-touch surfaces in healthcare facilities via powder coating over ductworks and furniture, can be used as additives in paints, integrated into air-filters, or directly incorporated into water filtration.

The antimicrobial benefits of metals (e.g. silver, copper) are well established, with decades of research demonstrating their effectiveness to kill a wide variety of bacteria, viruses, and fungi through simple surface contact. However, the application of metals has been difficult in practical settings, and our innovative product (based on proprietary technology) provides an elegant approach.

Nano-Product Engineering LLC (NPE) has developed a process for manufacturing coated microparticles, which are synthesized by applying a thin biocidal metal coating over high porosity, high surface-area core particles. This is achieved with a novel physical vapor deposition system in a fluidized bed reactor for feedstock powder handling. This results in a highly enhanced active surface area, which results in a more effective and longer lasting product than conventional microparticles. At the same time, our particles are micron-sized, which avoids problems of nanotoxicity. In other words, our particles have the advantages of being nano-structured, but without the disadvantages of being nano-sized. To achieve this unique high surface-area product, we rely on a proprietary low-temperature plasma process. Because our process is performed in vacuum, the resulting powder is free of any organic or inorganic contaminants. This provides a distinct advantage over conventional wet-chemical techniques, which can leave behind harmful chemical residues.

While both copper and silver have been proven to be effective antimicrobial agents, our product is based on copper coating, for cost reasons. Copper is typically ~100 times cheaper than silver.

An important commercialization consideration is that our process is highly scalable, such that our lab prototype production facilities can be scaled up to produce industrial levels (tons/year) of product. On an industrial scale, our process provides a significant price advantage over conventional copper-coated powders. We estimate a sales price of $0.06/cc for NPE’s higher-quality antimicrobial core-shell powder, compared to $0.20/cc for copper-impregnated charcoal powder currently available on the market.

The broader impact and commercial potential of this project is based on the improvement of antiviral/antimicrobial properties of water and air filters, ductwork, high-contact surfaces, respiratory equipment and PPE. Commercially available face masks, gowns and other PPE are continuously contaminated by exposure to the environment, posing a threat to healthcare personnel. Improved user protection from infections and reduced cross-contamination will result in fewer deaths, decreased healthcare costs, and increased economic productivity. The initial customer base will be healthcare personnel, pharmaceutical and food manufacturing facilities, and even the general public, expanding to manufacturers of PPE, medical devices, drugs, food, textiles, and filters.

The commercialization risks of novel functional nanomaterials are commonly limited by nanotoxicology concerns which, in many cases, prevents the nanoparticles from FDA approval or by myriad other practical aspects (i.e., off-target effects, costs, production yield, durability, environmental impacts, etc.). In contrast, our larger microparticles by design do not have nanotoxicity risk. Our process is environmentally friendly as it is based on a low-temperature plasma, as opposed to more common wet-chemical techniques. Because of this, the microparticles are free of any chemical surface residues which improves their biocidal efficacy and prevents poisoning of the usage sites. The dry core-shell powders produced by our process overcome the application challenges of conventional powders as they can be integrated in any type of fabric or composites, used in water filters or spray-dry coated over ductwork. The biocidal core-shell powder can be suspended in water or other solvents or mixed with binder such as acrylic resin and sprayed onto any solid surface to provide antimicrobial properties.

Microbiological testing of our antimicrobial core-shell powder was conducted to assess antimicrobial properties over a range of contact times. Test method ASTM E2149 was selected due to its suitability for antimicrobial properties of powders. Escherichia coli (E. coli) was selected as the test organism because of its prevalence in contamination of healthcare, food, and water facilities. The testing results demonstrated that biocidal core-shell powders manufactured in our process significantly reduced E. coli concentration by over four orders of magnitude, from an initial level of ~ 105 CFU/mL to below the detection limit of 5 CFU/mL within 1 hour of contact, as demonstrated in the diagram (Figure 2).
